[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami|Auxiliary Bishop of Miami]] (1997â2003) | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1950|10|18}} | birth_place = [[West Palm Beach, Florida|West Palm Beach]], [[Florida]] | death_date = | death_place = | buried = | nationality = | religion = | residence = | parents = | spouse = | children = | occupation = | profession = | alma_mater = | signature = }} '''Thomas Gerard Wenski''' (born October 18, 1950) is an [[United States|American]] [[prelate]] of the [[Roman Catholic Church]]. He is currently [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami|Archbishop of Miami]], having been appointed by [[Pope Benedict XVI]] on April 20, 2010 and installed on June 1, 2010.{{cite news|date=2010-04-20|work=[[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]]|title=Pope Names Orlando Bishop As Archbishop Of Miami, Chicago Auxiliary Bishop As Bishop Of Springfield In Illinois|url=http://www.usccb.org/comm/archives/2010/10-071.shtml}}{{cite news|date=2010-04-20|work=[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami]]|title='Native son' comes home|url=http://www.miamiarch.org/ip.asp?op=Article_1042019523157|last=Rodriguez-Soto|first=Ana}}{{cite news|date=2010-04-20|work=[[Associated Press]]|title=Miami archbishop resigns, Orlando bishop replaces|url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5isGqMl--y0X6NPtvO2PuDFsYJEFwD9F6UN100|last=Sedensky|first=Matt}} He previously served as [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando|Bishop of Orlando]] (2004â2010), [[coadjutor bishop]] of Orlando (2003â04), and [[auxiliary bishop]] of Miami (1997â2003).{{cite news|work=Catholic-Hierarchy.org|title=Bishop Thomas Gerard Wenski|url=http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/bishop/bwenski.html}} ==Early life and education== Wenski was born in [[West Palm Beach, Florida|West Palm Beach]], [[Florida]], to Chester and Louise (nÃ©e Zawacki) Wenski.{{cite news|date=1995-02-26|work=[[The Miami Herald]]|title=God's Man in Little Haiti|last=Viglucci|first=Andres}} His father was born in [[Poland]] with the last name '''Wisniewski''', and came to the [[United States]] with his parents in 1910 at age 2.{{cite news|date=2004-04-15|work=The Florida Catholic|title=Coadjutor joins in traditional Polish blessing|url=http://www.orlandodiocese.org/media/fl_catholic/Orl_04_15.pdf|last=St. Pierre|first=Mary}} The family eventually adopted the [[Anglicisation|Anglicized]] version, '''Wenski'''. Both Chester and his wife were raised in the Polish neighborhoods of [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], but moved to Florida after their marriage. Together they ran a business [[Spray painting|spray-painting]] [[stucco]] houses. Wenski was raised in [[Lake Worth, Florida|Lake Worth]], where he attended Sacred Heart School.{{cite news|work=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando]]|title=Bishop Wenski Biography|url=http://www.orlandodiocese.org/who_we_are/bishop_wenski/wenski_bio.php}} He decided to become a [[Priesthood (Catholic Church)|priest]] in the third grade, later recalling, "I never imagined myself as anything else; it was what God wanted me to do, although I sometimes vacillated on whether I wanted to do it."{{cite news|date=1997-09-03|work=[[South Florida Sun-Sentinel]]|title=Call Of Two Shepherds|url=http://articles.sun-sentinel.com/1997-09-03/lifestyle/9709020249_1_wenski-catholic-charities-auxiliary-bishop}} At age 13, he entered St. John Vianney Minor Seminary in [[Miami]].[http://stjohnvianneyseminary.org/ St. John Vianney Minor Seminary] During his twelve years at the seminary, he was a self-described "very liberal seminarian," questioning Catholic teaching on [[Clerical celibacy (Catholic Church)|clerical celibacy]] and the [[ordination of women]]. His views eventually became more conservative through his experience working with [[Cuba]]n immigrants and [[migrant worker]]s, running a summer camp for [[African American]] children, and reading about [[communism]] in Poland and Cuba. He graduated from St. John Vianney in 1970 with an [[Associate's degree]].{{cite news|date=2009-10-08|work=Florida Catholic|title=Seminarian's mural honors Mary|url=http://www.thefloridacatholic.org/mia/2009_mia/2009_miaarticles/20091008_mia_mural.php|last=Quaroni|first=Marlene}} Wenski then began his studies in [[philosophy]] and [[theology]] at St. Vincent de Paul Major Seminary in [[Boynton Beach, Florida|Boynton Beach]].[http://www.svdp.edu/ St. Vincent de Paul Major Seminary] He there earned a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in Philosophy (1972) and a [[Master of Divinity]] degree (1975). He later received a [[Master of Arts (postgraduate)|Master of Arts]] degree from the School of Sociology of [[Fordham University]] in 1993,[http://www.fordham.edu/academics/programs_at_fordham_/sociology__anthropol/ School of Sociology] and took summer courses at the [[John Paul II Catholic University of Lublin|Catholic University of Lublin]] in Poland. ==Priesthood== Wenski was [[Holy Orders|ordained]] a priest for the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami|Archdiocese of Miami]] by Archbishop [[Coleman Carroll]] on May 15, 1976. His first assignment was as an [[Curate|associate pastor]] at Corpus Christi Church in Miami,[http://www.corpuschristimiami.com/ Corpus Christi Church] where he remained for three years. At Corpus Christi, he took an interest in the [[Haiti]]an parishioners who attended [[Mass (liturgy)|Mass]] in [[Haitian Creole language|Creole]], and was sent to Haiti to study Creole and Haitian culture. When he returned to Miami in 1979, he was appointed to a Haitian apostolate operating out of the [[Cathedral of Saint Mary in Miami|Cathedral of Saint Mary]]. Wenski then served as associate director and later director of the Pierre Toussaint Haitian Catholic Center in Miami until 1997. He also served concurrently as [[pastor]] of three Haitian parishes in the archdiocese: Notre-Dame d'Haiti Church in Miami,[http://www.miamiarch.org/ip.asp?op=Search_PS&id=5713175141152 Notre-Dame d'Haiti Church] [http://www.saintpetersaintcharles.parishesonline.com/scripts/HostedSites/Org.asp?ID=19153 Divine Mercy Church] in [[Fort Lauderdale, Florida|Fort Lauderdale]], and St. Joseph in [[Pompano Beach, Florida|Pompano Beach]]. His outreach to the Haitian Catholic community in Miami was originally met with staunch opposition by Haitian priest and activist [[GÃ©rard Jean-Juste]], who eventually came to regard Wenski as an ally. He also befriended [[Jean-Bertrand Aristide]], a priest who later became the first democratically-elected [[List of heads of state of Haiti|President of Haiti]]. Wenski celebrated the weekly Mass in English for shut-ins at the [[WPLG|local ABC affiliate]] from 1992 to 1997, and directed the Ministry to Non-Hispanic Ethnic Groups. He became an adjunct professor at St. Vincent de Paul Seminary in 1994.[http://www.flacathconf.org/aboutus/bishops/wenski.htm] In January 1996, he was named director of the archdiocesan [[Catholic Charities]]. In this capacity, he helped form a relationship with ''Caritas Cuba'', the social service arm of the [[Roman Catholicism in Cuba|Catholic Church in Cuba]]. Later that year, he spearheaded a relief operation that delivered over 150,000 pounds of food to ''Caritas Cuba'' for distribution to people left homeless by [[Hurricane Lili (1996)|Hurricane Lili]]. ==Episcopacy== ===Auxiliary Bishop of Miami=== On June 24, 1997, Wenski was appointed [[auxiliary bishop]] of Miami and [[titular bishop]] of [[Kearney, Nebraska|Kearney]] by [[Pope John Paul II]]. He received his [[Bishop (Catholic Church)|episcopal]] [[consecration]] on the following September 3 from Archbishop [[John Favalora]], with Archbishop [[Edward A. McCarthy]] and Bishop [[Agustin Roman]] serving as [[Consecrator|co-consecrators]], at the [[Miami Arena]]. He selected as his episcopal [[motto]]: "All Things to All Men" ({{bibleverse|1|Corinthians|9:22}}).{{cite news|work=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando]]|title=Bishop Wenski Coat of Arms|url=http://www.orlandodiocese.org/who_we_are/bishop_wenski/wenski_coa.php}} As an auxiliary bishop, he served as [[Vicar general|episcopal vicar]] for [[Broward County, Florida|Broward]] and [[Monroe County, Florida|Monroe Counties]]. In addition to his episcopal duties, Wenski served on numerous boards including Catholic Hospice, Catholic Charities, Catholic Charities Legal Services, and St. Thomas University. He served as [[Chair (official)|chair]] of Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc. (1998â2001),[http://www.cliniclegal.org/ Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc.] and of the [[United States Conference of Catholic Bishops]]' Committee on Migration (2001â2004).[http://www.usccb.org/mrs/committeemigration.shtml Committee on Migration] He also served on [[Miami-Dade County, Florida|Miami-Dade County]]'s Homeless Trust and the Coordinating Council of Broward, and was appointed by Governor [[Jeb Bush]] to the Florida Council on Homelessness in 2001 and the Task Force on Haiti in 2004. ===Bishop of Orlando=== Wenski was appointed [[Coadjutor Bishop]] of the [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando|Diocese of Orlando]] on July 1, 2003. His installation took place on August 22 of that year. Following the retirement of Bishop [[Norbert Dorsey]], Wenski succeeded him as the fourth [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando|Bishop of Orlando]] on November 13, 2004. He was the first Florida-born Bishop of Orlando.{{cite news|work=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando]]|title=Diocese of Orlando History|url=http://www.orlandodiocese.org/who_we_are/history/index.php}} Wenski convoked the first [[synod]] for the Diocese of Orlando in 2004. He held listening sessions with a diverse group of Catholics to hear about their concerns and hopes for the future for the diocese. He designated 2008 as the "Year of Evangelization," putting a greater emphasis on deepening the faith of all people. At the time of his appointment to Miami in 2010, he was leading the diocese through the early stages of both a $150 million capital campaign and an extensive renovation of [[St. James Cathedral in Orlando|St. James Cathedral]].{{cite news|date=2010-04-20|work=Whispers in the Loggia|title=Holy Goalie: A Two-Pole Tuesday|url=http://whispersintheloggia.blogspot.com/2010/04/holy-goalie-two-pole-tuesday.html|last=Palmo|first=Rocco}} In October 2007, he was selected to serve on the Board of Directors of The Florida Specialty Crop Foundation, a non-profit public charity that responds to challenges that confront specialty crop producers and their stakeholders. In September 2008, he gave an invocation at the [[2008 Republican National Convention|Republican National Convention]] in [[Saint Paul, Minnesota|Saint Paul]], [[Minnesota]].{{cite news|work=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando]]|title=REPUBLICAN NATIONAL CONVENTION 2008 PRAYER - SEPTEMBER 2008|url=http://www.orlandodiocese.org/who_we_are/bishop_wenski/speeches/200809_rnc_prayer.php}} In March 2009, he joined the Catholic Leadership Institute's national advisory board for their "Good Leaders, Good Shepherds" program. In May of that year, Wenski held a Mass of Reparation for the [[University of Notre Dame]]'s decision to have [[President of the United States|President]] [[Barack Obama]] deliver its commencement speech and receive an [[honorary degree]], given Obama's [[pro-choice]] views.{{cite news|date=2009-05-05|work=[[Catholic News Agency]]|title=Bishop Wenski leads Mass of Reparation for Obama invite and Catholic 'complacency'|url=http://www.catholicnewsagency.com/news/bishop_wenski_leads_mass_of_reparation_for_obama_invite_and_catholic_complacency}} At the Mass, he denounced Obama for his "rather extremist views on [[abortion]]" and said that Notre Dame's "actions suggest that, unlike a [[Carrie Prejean|beauty queen from California]], it lacks the courage of its convictions."{{cite news|work=[[Roman Catholic Diocese of Orlando]]|title=Mass of Reparation - May 2009|url=http://www.orlandodiocese.org/who_we_are/bishop_wenski/homilies/200905_reparation.php}} In June 2009, he was elected to a four-year term on the [[Board of Trustees of The Catholic University of America|Board of Trustees]] of [[The Catholic University of America]]. He chaired of the USCCB Committee on International Policy (2004â2008), and currently serves as a consultant to the Committee on Migration and a member of the Secretariat for the Church in Latin America,[http://www.usccb.org/latinamerica/index.shtml Secretariat for the Church in Latin America] Committee for International Justice and Peace,[http://www.usccb.org/sdwp/international/ Committee for International Justice and Peace] and the Catholic Legal Immigration Network, Inc. He is currently the episcopal moderator for Catholic Health Services for the Florida Catholic Conference. [http://www.flacathconf.org/ Florida Catholic Conference] During his tenure, he created six new parishes and two missions.{{Cite news | first=Jennifer | last=Powers | title=Extended pastoral reach through new parishes, missions | url=| work= | publisher=Florida Catholic | location=Orlando, Florida | pages= A2 | date=May 21-June 3, 2010 | id= | accessdate=}} His capital and endowment campaign raised $100 million.{{Cite news | first=Teresa Lantigua | last=Peterson | title=Alive in Christ Campaign reaches $100 million | url=| work= | publisher=Florida Catholic | location=Orlando, Florida | pages= A3 | date=May 21-June 3, 2010 | id= | accessdate=}} He petitioned and was granted that two diocesan churches be raised to the status of minor [[basilica]]s.{{Cite news | first=Laura | last=Dobson | title=Churches elevated to status of minor basilicas under leadership of Archbishop Wenski | url=| work= | publisher=Florida Catholic | location=Orlando, Florida | pages= A14 | date=May 21-June 3, 2010 | id= | accessdate=}} He started the Spanish language radio station Buena Nueva FM along with the Spanish language newspaper, ''El Clarin.''{{Cite news | first=Tanya | last=Goodman | title=Helping Spanish-speaking Catholics feel at home | url=| work= | publisher=Florida Catholic | location=Orlando, Florida | pages= A16 | date=May 21-June 3, 2010 | id= | accessdate=}} The diocese spent $10 million upgrading the St. James cathedral in 2010. The upgraded building contained a new stained glass window commemorating the contribution of Wenski to building improvements.[http://dailyme.com/story/2010112000000563/stained-glass-controversy-archbishop-wenski-big.html] ===Archbishop of Miami=== On April 20, 2010, Wenski was appointed the fourth [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami|Archbishop of Miami]] by [[Pope Benedict XVI]]. Following his appointment, he said he was "humbled by the [[Pope|Holy Father]]'s confidence in me and aware of my own limitations and shortcomings..."{{cite news|date=2010-04-20|work=[[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Miami]]|title=Statement from Archbishop- Designate Thomas Wenski|url=http://www.miamiarch.org/ip.asp?op=Article_1041917190665}} He succeeded Archbishop [[John Favalora]]. He became the first native of the Archdiocese to become its archbishop. Wenski was installed at the Cathedral of Saint Mary on June 1, 2010. At the end of June, he received the [[pallium]], a vestment worn by [[metropolitan bishop]]s, from Pope Benedict XVI at [[St. Peter's Basilica]]. ==Footnotes== {{reflist|2}} ==External links== *[http://www.orlandodiocese.org/who_we_are/bishop_wenski/index.php Official Bishop Wenski page including columns, homilies and speeches] *[http://www.orlandodiocese.org/ Diocese of Orlando]
